thread.title: 10 things southerners won't understand about the north | Metro News
thread.title_full: 10 things southerners won't understand about the north | Metro News

author: Samuel Ramsden
title: 10 things southerners won't understand about the north | Metro News
text:
10 things southerners won’t understand about the north Samuel Ramsden Wednesday 22 Feb 2017 6:00 am There’s the north, and then there’s THE NORTH (Picture: HBO) 
Although the north is actually not too dissimilar to the south, or particularly far away from it, there are many aspects of the northern life that southerners simply don’t understand. 
If you hail from the south and plan on stepping foot up north anytime soon you might need to prepare yourself for a bit of a culture shock. 
Here are just some examples of what you might have no clue about. 1. Speaking To Strangers 
Southerners (whether it’s a fair assumption or not) have the reputation of not being the friendliest bunch especially when it comes to acknowledging strangers. 
Whether it’s simply smiling at someone in the street or speaking to your fellow commuters on public transport – it’s just not something that is regularly seen. 
It’s a stark contrast up in the north. 
You don’t have to worry about making awkward eye contact and digging your head into your mobile phones because most northerners will actually – deep breath – be willing to talk to you. 
It isn’t always the most stimulating conversation, but sometimes it’s nice to have a friendly chat about the weather on your morning commute – this is a concept which may seem quite alien to a born and bred southerner. 2. The weather Classic Scotland (Picture: Getty) 
To be fair the UK as a whole isn’t exactly known for it’s glorious weather, but up in the north the weather can actually be much harsher. 
The phrase ‘it’s grim up north’ wasn’t coined for no reason. 
The weather, however, is something northerners are completely unfazed by. 
It’s going to take more than a splash of rain to ruin a northerner’s night out. 3. Calling lunch ‘dinner’ 
Yes, this might be hard for southerners to swallow, but many in the north actually refer to lunchtime as ‘dinner’. 
If you hail from the south it’s probably best to be aware of this before heading up north as it could lead to a lot of confusion. 
Oh and to add insult to injury dinner is often referred to as ‘tea’ as well. 4. Greggs obsession Greggs, everywhere you look! (Picture: Greggs/Metro) 
While you might stumble across the odd Greggs down south, in the north there is almost no escape. 
Walk down any high street in the north and it won’t be one minute before you pass one of these delicious paradises. 
A lot of southerners may not understand the north’s affinity with Greggs, but after trying one of their pasties you might start to. 5. Gravy goes with everything 
To most southerners gravy is taken for granted. 
It’s simply something to complement a meal – whereas in the north it quite often IS the meal. 
Northerners understand that sometimes there’s nothing better than a roast dinner drowning in gravy and the classic ‘chips and gravy’ combination is basically considered a delicacy. 6. Southerners are all ‘soft’ 
If you’re a southerner in the north, it doesn’t matter how tough or intimidating you think you are – to northerners you are and always will be ‘soft’. 
It’s worth noting that northerners just love to tease you and this is another satisfying way of doing so, but many consider southerners being soft as a scientific fact. 7. Northern slang Brush up on your northern slang with a bit of Wallace and Gromit, chuck (Picture: BBC) 
Not only do northerners have a wide range of (sometimes hard to understand) accents, they also have some of the best slang. 
This slang makes perfect sense to other northerners – however to a southerner things can get very confusing, very quickly when exposed to these words. 
If you’re from the south and plan on visiting, perhaps read through the urban dictionary first. More
